Overview.Title: Choose the correct explanation why a claim of an argument is wrong
Overview.Text: An argument consists of a claim and a reason. In the simplest form, an argument can be read as: "Reason, therefore Claim" (or "Claim because Reason")
In order to infer the claim from a reason, one needs a "bridge" - reasoning and logic that explains why the given reason supports the claim.

However, in these HITs we are interested in claims that are not logically implied by the reason. We call them incorrect claims (for instance, in an argument about taking an umbrella, the incorrect claim would be "We shouln't take the umbrella" given the reason "It's about to start raining").
Your task in the HITs will be to write an explaination why the incorrect claim does not follow the reason.
In his qualification test you will learn how a proper explanation should look like.

List.ListItem: The explanation fills the reasoning gap between the reason and the incorrect claim.
The explanation must relate to the content of the given reason.
The explanation does not simply repeat or rephrases what's already said in the reason.
The explanation is kept short and does not add necessary or distracting information.
The explanation avoids starting with "because" or "the person says" or similar and avoids pronouns if possible.

QuestionContent.Title: Choose the proper explanation (see the criteria above) why the claim is incorrect given the reason; the argument is about grading colleges by the governmnet:
QuestionContent.Text: (Remember: "Reason, therefore Claim", which doesn't of course work for an incorrect claim)
Reason: "Rank-ordering colleges isn't necessary, because each would use the same standardized scale."

Selection.Text: It's unnecessary to rank colleges since they'd all use the same scale.

QuestionContent.Title: Choose the proper explanation (see the criteria above) why the claim is incorrect given the reason; the argument is about allowing to have new employees sign noncompete deals:
QuestionContent.Text: (Remember: "Reason, therefore Claim", which doesn't of course work for an incorrect claim)
Reason: "Businesses shouldn't be able to stop employees from getting better deal when the businesses themselves try to get what's best for their business."
Incorrect claim: "Businesses should be allowed to have new employees sign noncompete deals"

Selection.Text: Businesses are only looking out for their best interest, therefore they should also allow employees the same privilege.
Businesses should also allow employees the same privilege.
